item.title: Stop mass pk?
item.dc:creator: @X_F_U_R_Y_X X F U R Y X
item.description:
@X_F_U_R_Y_X wrote:

This is my attack() boolean… added it and it doesn’t work…

public boolean Attack() { if(actionTimer == 0) { //Continue with PKing actionTimer = 0; //Set the int you want here. } if(actionTimer > 0) { //Inform or stop the player because he attacked not too long ago. Do not allow the attack to continue. } int EnemyX = PlayerHandler.players[AttackingOn].absX; int EnemyY = PlayerHandler.players[AttackingOn].absY; int EnemyHP = PlayerHandler.players[AttackingOn].playerLevel[playerHitpoints]; int EnemyHPExp = PlayerHandler.players[AttackingOn].playerXP[playerHitpoints]; client AttackingOn2 = (client) server.playerHandler.players[AttackingOn]; boolean RingOfLife = false; if (PlayerHandler.players[AttackingOn].playerEquipment[playerRing] == 2570) { RingOfLife = true; }

And if this works, I’ll rep you…

Read full topic

item.title: Stop mass pk?
item.dc:creator: @TeleNubby TeleNubby
item.description:
@TeleNubby wrote:

Use actionTimer in your switch statements where the actions are performed when you click on the certain object or player. If it’s for players you will need to look at the boolean Attack().

When using actionTimer, check if it’s at zero before a player can successfully continue with the attack. If it’s above zero, that means the player has attacked not too long ago and has to wait. So if statements like these can be made (dont forget to set actionTimer when the player is attacking)

if(actionTimer == 0) {
    //Continue with PKing
    actionTimer = 0; //Set the int you want here.
}
if(actionTimer > 0) {
    //Inform or stop the player because he attacked not too long ago. Do not allow the attack to continue.
}

Read full topic
